This is now my favorite Chinese restaurant outside China. Awesome Jiangsu food! I'm much more satisfied with the food here than many Michelin restaurants I've tried in SF.
author: Chen P.

description: Food wasn't bad, just very little meat for the $ cost. Had to order more steak on the side and it was still tiny.
author: Ramz A.

description:
I really like the Mapo Tofu, one of the best I ever had. It was the right level of spiciness and the flavor was super good. 

The place was not very crowded, had a good clean and new ambience, and service was very good.
author: Gui K.

description: Really delicious new place on the Balboa Strip. Ordered the Napa cabbage and chicken and was a little nervous about my choice by the look of it - delightfully surprised when I took the first bite. Everything we ate was fantastic. Friendly atmosphere and employees. Definitely a new favourite in the neighbourhood. Will be back!
author: Madeline M.

description:
OMG. So good. We had the braised tofu, which was SO GOOD and flavorful. Then we had the braised pork and the short ribs (maybe only get one of them because it was a big rich). Also had the cabbage, which was delicious even though it's "just" cabbage, after all. 

Service was a tad slow and the place is small, but it was very yummy. Came out to $15/person, including tip.
author: B. Y.

description: Food was mediocre, service was indifferent and in a rush. It felt like they were doing me a favor serving me food. It was crowded and unwelcoming place that I am not planning to come back to.
author: Chelse D.

description: Stumbled upon this while hanging out in the city and decided to give this a try. We ended up ordering the lion head, braised pork, house special eggplant, and 1/2 soysauce duck. We thought it's cute the lady kept telling us we might be ordering too much instead of trying to hit make money from us. The food was really good, I think the only thing I felt was more standard was the lion head, which tasted good but similar to most restaurants. Other 3 were all really good, duck is super yummy but keep in mind the way it's prepared here doesn't have crispy skin so if thats what u like then this one might not be for u. The pork is very tender and comes with quail eggs (adorable and tasty). Will try to come back next time I come to the city again. Only minus is the typical Asian restaurant flaws: mediocre service and ambience but those things dont bother me much if the food is legit.
author: Cathleen L.

description: After our many attempts to find an open restaurant today we wound up in this little gem. It is quite a small restaurant but the food is great!! Coming from New York, we always have a variety of food and usually proclaimed some of the best in the nation. This food was the best because of the authenticity. Everything was fresh and made to order. Enjoyed each of my dishes and each was pleasantly tasty! I reccommend this place for anyone around the area!
author: Heather J.

description: The restaurant we wanted to go was closed so we went into the closest restaurant nearby, which happened to be Jiangnan. We ordered braised pork, pea shoot tips, mapo tofu, beef noodle soup, and fried rice with vegetable and shredded meat. Everything was excellent. It was a serendipitous surprise.
author: Yun W.

description: Very delicious! Food paradise! If you are currently scrolling down to read the reviews for this wonderful restaurant, don't hesitate, just go! You'll thank yourself! We literally LOVE everything we ordered! Will definitely be coming back next time we come to visit SF! :))
author: Kathrine R.

description: There is only one server, but the wait is definitely worth it. I got the braised pork, pork meatball, braised beef and potato, and fried rice with chicken. Braised pork = to die for. It's sooo good. The braised beef and potato is also extremely tasty.
author: Jackie L.

description: 5 star for the jiangnan food, it is exactly the same taste as in my hometown Wuxi. Minus 1 star for the annoying fact that there are many spicy foods in the menu that are not jiangnan cuisine at all, and they do not taste good.
author: Jack Y.

description: Really authentic southern Chinese food. Definitely try the tofu soup, braised pork, Napa cabbage, and eggplants. Definitely a go-to for Chinese food in the city.
author: Colleen Z.

description: Really good! Loved the spicy chicken and spicy beans. A winner for sure. Give it a try.
author: Kai L.

description: Only had one thing one time, but it was perfect: egg and tomato noodles, Wuxi style. kind of a soup. utterly yum.
author: Jane M.

description: This is authentic Chinese food. The flavors were not familiar to me but good. If you are looking for different flavors then this is a good place to try. The Lo Mein noodles were completely different than anything I have ever tasted. Try it.....you might like it too.
author: J O.

description:
I am glad to see this restaurant is doing well with people lining up outside. 

FINALLY there is a non Cantonese Chinese restaurant opened in SF besides those spicy sichuan and northern China food.  I say "finally" because I am not big into spicy food, and those northern China food usually just good on noodles, dumplings...I like them but need some more variation - a good Chinese dish.

I have been living in SF for 17 years now and am really tired about the very plain taste of Cantonese food which often tastes cheap.  Please do not get me wrong.  I love quality made dim sum and the steam fish done by the Cantonese seafood restaurant.  They do a great job.  However, if you are the immigrant who come from the region other than Canton Province, you know what I am talking about by the plain taste of Cantonese food.  Besides corn starch, black bean sauce and small garlic chunks are added into their dishes, there is no much flavor at all.

So, you see how happy I am that there is a good Chinese restaurant with Jiangnan flavor opened up in my neighborhood.  My friend and I have visited there three times now and most of the dishes we tried were pleasant.  The portion is a little bit small compared to the Cantonese restaurants, but it is Ok.  

The "lion's head" ($4.95 per piece) is a must try.  It tastes even better with plain rice (true for other meat dishes they have).  For this dish, they do a better job than many Chinese restaurants do in the greater China region.

The restaurant title in English "Jiangnan" means south of the Yang zi Jiang (river), and in general it indicates to the area in the broad southern region.  The title in Chinese is "Su Wei Guan".  Su is the ancient title of the province "Jiang Su".  "Wei" means the taste/flavor.  "Guan" here is another word for restaurant.  I like it.  They picked up a nice name.

Everything else is good.  Servers are sincerely friendly, and the kitchen staffs do a good job.  Restroom is very tiny.  So if you are not a petite size, visit a restroom first before you come.

A few suggestions to the restaurant:
1. Lower the volume of the music - it makes the background too noisy.
2. Remove the valet use table/desk at the entrance - It makes the entry and exist unpleasant.
3. Put some cushions on the wooden bench along the wall - too hard to sit on.
4. Menu - adds a brief intro to your food and its region.


* In my opinion, you can find very few nice Chinese food (non Cantonese) in SF.  You need to drive to the south bay to find them.  I called it "the belt" region from Mountain View down to Cupertino, San Jose, Milpitas, and up to Union City and Fremont.
author: TG B.

description: It's been a while since I've been inspired to write a review. This place is great. I'm not going down the route of best ever or most authentic place in San Francisco because that's just unnecessary. With all of the Chinese restaurants we have in the Richmond district it's nice to find one that stands out and offers unique flavors for a fair price. At least in my experience,  it's very rare that you find a Chinese restaurant that specializes in braised meats. You can tell a lot of care is taken in the food prep and it appears to be a small family run place, but I could be wrong. I intend to go back to try much of the menu but today I can speak to the braised pork, Mapo Tofu, lions head meatball and the spicy pork. All were spot on.
author: John D.

description: We came here for dinner,the food was so amazing! I recommend ordering the stewed duck in soy sauce（pre-order),  so yummy! The service was good and the atmosphere was clean!
author: Chuan Y.

description: Had my first meal there today, a lunch of mapo tofu, which Jiangnan has on the menu as made with chicken. It was super tasty: firm tofu, ground chicken, nice presence of pepper, good heat, all over a healthy serving of rice. It came to ... $4. I left a $2 out of sheer guilt. Can't wait to go back. Maybe as soon as tomorrow!
author: OuterLands X.

description: Wanted to check out this new place. Great affordable and tasty food! I went for dinner and the portions are generous. I saw their lunch special and can't wait to try it!
author: Tina C.

description: Officially surpassing taste of jiangnan and becoming my favorite place in the Bay Area. I'm requesting more branches/expansion of the restaurant so that I don't need to wait for 1-2 hours every single time.
author: Kaiyan Z.

description: Wow, wow, wow.  7 of us ate here last Saturday for lunch--had a wide variety of dishes.  The eggplant was amazing, cabbage with chicken, half duck--the chicken with potatoes was complex with flavor and much more delicious than you might think from the simple name.  The ma po with chicken was great.  Warm welcome and service.  Will definitely come back for more.  Good stuff.
author: David J.

description: Went here during this Memorial Day weekend, food was delicious and very authentic. The entire restaurant staff were extremely welcoming and friendly, which made me and my friends feel very comfortable. I highly recommend this place to anyone looking for authentic Jiangnan/Chinese food or just something tasty in general!
author: Bonnie C.

description: This is Suzhou-nese food to be clear, if there's such a category on yelp. I'm from Suzhou China. And to be honest, the food here is pretty close to what I had back in my hometown. The duck dish and the shrimp with special sauce are a must-try.
author: Daniel Z.

description: We live in the neighborhood and noticed this recently opened restaurant shares the style of interior design of our other favorite Jiangnan cuisine place on Clement. Today, my mother and I, both native Shanghainese, went there for lunch. We ordered sweet sour ribs, salty pork and green fried rice, and sautéed string beans. All of them are very good! I recognized the manager of the place, whom I saw months ago working at Taste of Jiangnan on Clement. And she told me her team used to train the chef and staff at ToJ but the owner wanted to add other cuisines to the menu, so she and her team left. I am so glad that her team ended up opening this one in our neighborhood! Service is quick and staff very friendly. What I also appreciate about this place is its limited menu. They cook authentic Jiangnan dishes, and cook them well.
author: Fang X.

description: Had a pleasant experience here! Friendly service, along with tasty food! Their "homemade meat ball in sauce", "maps tofu", and the "braised pork" are a must have here. Overall, would definitely come back to try out other stuff on the menu!
author: Annie W.

description: Wanted to try something local and took a chance on this little place. Very pleasantly surprised!  Very friendly staff.  Good food -- not heavy on sauces or anything greasy. Very flavorful.  Will definitely go back again. It's small and gets busy so be prepared to wait a little or get takeout (saw a number of those.)
author: James S.

description: Wow!! Super delicious! We had the Lion's meatball and could hardly resist licking the bowl. So we didn't ! Then we had the sumptuous duck (half portion without bones plenty for two). Yummy! Finger-licking yummy! Lovely and friendly service. Cannot wait to return. And we shall.
author: Tina C.

description: Great food. Nice atmosphere. Good friendly service. The cousine is south of Shanghai,  rather rich in flavor.
author: Ilya K.

description: This place is very authentic Jiangsu food. Highly recommend for braised pork, boiled cabbage and small rice balls in rice soup.
author: Peter L.

description: Food was great. The wait is little long but the restaurant is small so that is expected. We ordered three dishes and it was all good. Would come again. It can get stuffy since there isn't much air circulation.
author: Chung Fai S.

description: Just came back from visiting this particular region in China. The food at this restaurant is the closest I've had to what's over there. The service was warm and friendly. The mapo tofu and home made meatballs are excellent. Overall price was reasonable too. This is definitely a new gem in the outer richmond.
author: M B.

description:
The restaurant is small. The menu is simple but the taste is exceptional. We like the tofu soup with very silky layered tofu, tender lions head, great duck with soy sauce, rice soup with shrimp and chicken meat, etc. We'll certainly goo back. 
The parking is very difficult. You could be waiting for you table for a long while.
author: Steve W.

description: A small restaurant, just big enough to feel the mom n' pop shop's warmth.  Food is authentic and well done.  We ordered too much for the four of us, which is a happy accident.  I love having enough leftovers to not have to cook the next night.  Lion's head was tender and juicy, a winner with the kids.  The portion of the braised shrimp was generous to say the least---this would have made sense in the real Jiangnan, where river shrimp are small, so when you spoon them up and dip them in vinegar, you can easily fit 5-6 in one bite.  We have bigger shrimps here, so the dish seems, massive, when it's pretty much nothing but shrimps, all 30-40 of them.  Wuxi wonton was perfect, in both the subtle umami taste of the broth and the silky wonton skins.  One of my favorite was the spareribs.  Something so pedestrian, something that you seem to able to master easily at home, but actually rarely done so well, with the perfect blend of sweet and tang, fat and acid.  Strings beans and rice cakes with mustard green were good too. But I think any decent Chinese restaurants would have made them quite well.
author: Candice B.

description: Loved this place! We had shrimp in Maggie's sauce, the meatball, vegetable rice with salted meat and mapo tofu. Everything was excellent. The meatball was a lovely surprise - very juicy, rich and perfectly sauced. The mapo tofu was as good as I've ever had it. The tofu itself was wonderfully fresh and just perfectly textured. The other two dishes were excellent as well. The giant shrimp were perfectly cooked and the rice was a nice alternative to the standard friend rice. Definitely plan on going back!
author: Maggie L.

description: Poor service, average food for the price.  We arrived on a Thu (8/17) just at opening and were seated in the front.  We ordered the beef chow mein, eggplant dish, and won ton soup.  We wanted to order green beans, but the server said the quality was poor.  All were $11.99.  Since we expected the food to be spicy, we also ordered a couple of small bowls of rice ($1.25/ea) .  The waitress had some difficulties explaining the dishes to us.  Her helper brought out the chow mein and the eggplant dish first and not the soup.  Finally the soup arrived.  Generally the soup is served first.  There are no condiments on the table such as salt, pepper, soy sauce, hot sauce which are typical of Asian restaurants.  They never brought out the rice.  The food was good to average and is about 20-50% higher than a typical Chinese restaurant.  Of course, people pay the higher price for quality and ambience, but this place didn't have it.  The music was way too loud and we had to ask them to turn it down.  After finishing our meal, we had to wave down the servers to get take out boxes and the check.  People were waiting to be seated and it was crowded at the entrance that one woman leaned against my chair and finally moved away when I looked in her direction.  Unlikely that we would return.  Probably a 2-1/2 star.
author: Robert J.

description: Visited after a large festival in Golden Gate Park - along with many other music lovers and some local regulars.  Kudos to the kitchen for managing the large influx.  Walking through the kitchen to get to the restrooms, I was impressed at the chefs' efficiency in a relatively small space - particularly given the menu's variety.  Only hiccup was that I only intended to order one soup, depending on which of two options could be made vegetarian, and instead both were brought to the table (along with the two entrees and order of  vegetarian spring rolls); too much for two, but I like leftovers.  Best dish was the Wuxi Style Tofu Soup with irregular tender platelets of tofu (instead of the usual cubes), lots of mushrooms, and some nori (and probably not a vegetarian stock); next best was the cabbage dish heading up the Vegetables section of the menu.  The Eggplant without meat was fine though a bit sweet, the vegetarian spring rolls were as expected, and the Xianghai Yang Chun Noodle Soup was good but a little boring.  All of the dishes were served piping hot.
author: Peni Soo G.

description: If you are Shanghinese and miss hometown cooking, you won't regret coming here.  Call to ask about the preorder dishes too.  We ordered 8 dishes.  You could tell the cook had carefully crafted the flavor of each dish.
author: Herman Y.

description: One of the best places to eat in SF. I love the duck. All the dishes I have tried are delicious.
author: Angela C.

description: So delicious! Very great restaurant! I come to dinner tonight, I try sweet and sour pork, lion head meatball, braised pork. The food very authentic,  find my childhood memories! Will come more often.
author: Cabby S.

description: This is by far one of the best Jiangnan restaurants in San Francisco. Every dish I've had on the menu has been phenomenal. My favorites are the braised pork with quail eggs, salted meat and vegetable fried rice, and stir-fried tomatoes and eggs. The owners are extremely friendly and knowledgeable about what goes into every dish. One time, we sat way past closing time, but the chef even accommodated us when we decided to add on a last dish half an hour past closing. Make sure to join their WeChat group for discounts during October 2017.
author: Andrew W.

description: OMG. I can't believe I found a place like this. Absolutely love EVERYTHING here. Authentic and simply yummy. The duck needs to be ordered before noon or else it's gone. The ones that appreciate the Jiangnan flavor will understand why it's gone so quick. Because it's soooo good!!! The sauce was not made with loads of starch (to thicken). Instead it's completely made just sauce and sugar. Let me say this again. OMG, I'm so glad I found this place.
author: Ji R.
